cards.name: Chernobyl Tree Frogs
cards.flavorText: Tree frogs near Chernobyl evolved darker skin pigmentation to resist ionizing radiation.

cards.name: Confusing Rocket Frog
cards.flavorText: Allobates femoralis males wrestle rivals and carry tadpoles on their backs to scattered pools.

cards.name: Desert Rain Frog
cards.flavorText: Breviceps macrops burrows in Namibian coastal sand dunes and squeaks like a dog toy when threatened.

cards.name: Emperor Newt
cards.flavorText: Tylototriton shanjing secretes toxins through bony ribs that pierce its own skin as a defense.

cards.name: Fire Salamander
cards.flavorText: Fire salamanders spray neurotoxic alkaloids from glands behind their eyes up to several meters.

cards.name: Frost's Toad
cards.flavorText: Incilius cristatus lives in cloud forests above 1,800m and breeds only in cold mountain streams.

cards.name: Golden-flecked Glass Frog
cards.flavorText: Glass frogs hide red blood cells in their liver while sleeping, becoming nearly transparent to predators.

cards.name: Golden Mantellas
cards.flavorText: Golden mantellas are endemic to a single swamp in eastern Madagascar, spanning just 10 sq km.

cards.name: Golden Poison Frog
cards.flavorText: One golden poison frog holds enough batrachotoxin to kill 10 humans. It gets its toxin from its diet.

cards.name: Java Flying Frog
cards.flavorText: Rhacophorus reinwardtii glides up to 15 meters between trees using oversized webbed feet as parachutes.

cards.name: Monte Iberia Eleuth
cards.flavorText: At just 10mm long, the Monte Iberia eleuth is one of the world's smallest tetrapods.

cards.name: Panamanian Golden Frog
cards.flavorText: Presumed extinct in the wild, it communicates via semaphore-like hand waving since waterfalls drown out calls.

cards.name: Phantasmal Poison Frog
cards.flavorText: Epipedobates tricolor produces epibatidine, a painkiller 200 times stronger than morphine.

cards.name: Purple Frog
cards.flavorText: The purple frog spends 50 weeks underground eating termites, surfacing only during monsoon to breed.

cards.name: Red-tailed Knobby Newts
cards.flavorText: These newts push sharp rib tips through their skin to inject toxin into a predator's mouth.

cards.name: Siberian Salamander
cards.flavorText: Can survive being frozen at -35C for years by producing glycerol antifreeze in its tissues.

cards.name: Turtle Frog
cards.flavorText: Myobatrachus gouldii digs headfirst with muscular arms to reach termite nests in Australian sand.

cards.name: Tomato Frog
cards.flavorText: When grabbed, tomato frogs secrete a thick white glue from their skin that numbs predators' eyes.

cards.name: Hippo Frog
cards.flavorText: Hemisus marmoratus headbutts into soil to burrow and can eat prey nearly as large as itself.

cards.name: Surinam Toad
cards.flavorText: Females embed fertilized eggs into spongy back skin, where tadpoles develop and erupt as fully formed frogs.

cards.name: Axolotl
cards.flavorText: Axolotls can regenerate limbs, spinal cord, heart tissue, and even parts of their brain without scarring.

cards.name: Bigfoot Leopard Frog
cards.flavorText: Discovered in 2012, Lithobates megapoda has disproportionately large hind feet for navigating rocky streams.

cards.name: Indian Bullfrog
cards.flavorText: Males turn bright yellow during breeding season. They eat insects, mice, and even small snakes.

cards.name: American Bullfrogs
cards.flavorText: American bullfrogs eat anything that fits in their mouth: birds, bats, snakes, and other frogs.

cards.name: Mountain Chicken
cards.flavorText: Named for tasting like chicken, Leptodactylus fallax is critically endangered with fewer than 8,000 left.

cards.name: Titicaca Water Frog
cards.flavorText: Its excessive loose skin folds increase surface area for absorbing oxygen from Lake Titicaca at 3,800m.

cards.name: African Bullfrog
cards.flavorText: Males guard tadpole pools and dig channels to connect drying puddles, saving thousands of offspring.

cards.name: Cane Toad
cards.flavorText: Introduced to Australia in 1935 for pest control, cane toads now number over 200 million there.

cards.name: Goliath Frog
cards.flavorText: The world's largest frog at 3.3kg. It moves rocks up to half its body weight to build river nests.

cards.name: Hellbender Salamander
cards.flavorText: North America's largest salamander at 74cm. It breathes entirely through its wrinkled skin underwater.

cards.name: Helmeted Water Toad
cards.flavorText: Calyptocephalella gayi has a bony, helmet-like skull used to block burrow entrances from predators.

cards.name: Lake Junin Giant Frog
cards.flavorText: Endemic to Peru's Lake Junin at 4,080m elevation, it is one of the highest-dwelling frogs on Earth.

cards.name: Japanese Giant Salamander
cards.flavorText: Up to 1.5m long, it hunts by ambush using sensory nodes on its head to detect water vibrations.

cards.name: Chinese Giant Salamander
cards.flavorText: The largest living amphibian at 1.8m. Its vocalizations sound eerily like a crying human baby.

cards.name: Ambiguity
cards.flavorText: Many amphibians can switch sex under environmental stress, blurring the line between male and female.

cards.name: Bounce
cards.flavorText: Frogs absorb water through a permeable patch on their belly instead of drinking with their mouths.

cards.name: Leapfrog
cards.flavorText: Some frogs can leap 20 times their body length in a single bound using elastic tendon energy storage.

cards.name: Monsoon
cards.flavorText: Tropical monsoons trigger mass amphibian breeding events with thousands spawning in a single night.

cards.name: Pounce Plummet
cards.flavorText: Red-eyed tree frogs use startle coloration, flashing bright eyes and flanks to confuse lunging predators.

cards.name: Shower
cards.flavorText: Amphibian skin secretes antimicrobial peptides now being studied as next-generation antibiotics.

cards.name: Terrain Shift
cards.flavorText: Amphibians are bioindicators: their permeable skin makes them the first to vanish when ecosystems degrade.

cards.name: Whitewater
cards.flavorText: Torrent frogs have enlarged toe pads and muscular legs to cling to rocks in fast-flowing rapids.

cards.name: Metamorphosis
cards.flavorText: Metamorphosis remodels nearly every organ: gills become lungs, tails are reabsorbed, and the jaw restructures.

cards.name: Newt
cards.flavorText: Newts regenerate entire limbs, lens tissue, and cardiac muscle throughout their lives without tumors.

cards.name: Sleight of Hand
cards.flavorText: Frog toe pads use wet adhesion: nanopillar structures and mucus create grip strong enough to climb glass.

cards.name: Slime
cards.flavorText: Frog mucus contains over 100 unique compounds, some antiviral enough to neutralize influenza strains.

cards.name: Blowdart
cards.flavorText: Choco people rub dart tips on golden poison frogs; one frog can coat 50 darts that stay lethal for years.

cards.name: Rebound
cards.flavorText: Frogs use their eyeballs to swallow food, retracting them into the mouth to push prey down the throat.

cards.name: Slip
cards.flavorText: Amphibian skin mucus inspired biomimetic coatings that reduce surgical adhesions and infection rates.
